(Photo: SAUL LOEB, AFP/Getty Images) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Thursday the Trump administration aims to pass “significant” tax reform, including tax cuts for middle-class Americans, by August but it will likely be late next year before the changes juice economic growth. 
“The number one issue is growth and the most important thing that will impact growth is a tax plan,” Mnuchin said on CNBC in his first televised interview. “We are committed to passing tax reform. It’s going to be very significant. It’s going to be focused on middle class tax cuts and making the business tax more competitive with the rest of the world.” 
Most corporations pay a federal tax rate of 35%, highest among advanced economies. Pres. Trump has proposed reducing the rate to 15%. Mnuchin said the high rate “is some of the reason companies are leaving and cash is sitting offshore.” 
Mnuchin said the administration is “working closely with leaders in the House and Senate” and is looking to have a plan passed by Congress’s August recess. He would not say when any tax cuts would take effect or whether they could be retroactive. 
While he said the cuts would be integral to achieving the administration’s goal of at least 3% economic growth, a level called “very achievable.” The economy has been growing about 2% a year since the recession ended in June 2009. 
But he added, “I think it’s going to take time to get (to a 3% growth pace), more toward the end of next year.” 
For wealthy households, Mnuchin said the tax cuts being “offset with reductions of deductions and other things.” 
The Treasury secretary said cutting back regulations would be the other major initiative in the campaign to improve economic growth. 
“We need to cut back regulations that have prevented small and midsize businesses from being the engines of growth in this country and were also focused on banks and making sure banks can lend.” 
Asked about a proposed border adjustment tax on imports, Mnuchin said, “we are looking at it. We think there are some very interesting aspects of it. We think there are some concerns with it.” 
While many US manufacturers support such attacks, retailers vigorously oppose it, fearing it will raise prices for consumers and hammer their profits. 
Addressing the record market rally since Trump was elected, Mnuchin said he thinks he represents justifiable market confidence in the ministrations progrowth policies. 
“There’s a lot of confidence in the Trump administration and in the desire to be invested in the US,” he said. “This is a mark to market business and you see what the market thinks.” CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://usat.ly/2mbPaui NEVER MISS OUT Managing Your Money Master your money with the latest business and investment news, articles and tips from financial experts each Friday.
